find.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: to discover, see, or get something that you have been searching for
find.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: I can’t find the car keys.
Hold on while I find a pen.
Her body was later found hidden in the bushes.
I have to find somewhere else to live.
She had almost given up hope of finding a husband.
Her mother went to the shops, and on her return, Kathleen was nowhere to be found (=could not be found).
Tony asked us to find him office facilities in New York.
find.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: to discover something by chance, especially something useful or interesting
find.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: I found a purse in the street.
We found a nice pub near the hotel.
find.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: to discover that someone or something is in a particular condition or doing a particular thing when you see or touch them
find.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: I’m sure we’ll find her hard at work when we get home.
He tried the door and found it unlocked.
She woke to find a man by her bed.
Often he found her quietly weeping alone.
She looked at her glass and was amazed to find it was empty.
find.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: to be in a particular state or do a particular thing, or to realize that this is happening, especially when you did not expect or intend it
find.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: After wandering around, we found ourselves back at the hotel.
When he left, Karen found herself heaving a huge sigh of relief.
find yourself/your mind etc doing something
She tried to concentrate, but found her mind drifting back to Alex.
find yourself/your mind etc doing something
find.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: to discover or learn something by study, tests, sums etc
find.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: The federal government isn’t doing enough to find a cure.
How do you find the square root of 20?
The liquid was found to contain 7.4g of phenylamine.
His study found that married men and women had similar spending patterns.
find.translation[0].definitions[4].note_: In more formal English, you say it was found that something was true
It was found that over 50% of children had seen the ad
find.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: to have a particular feeling or opinion, or to have a particular feeling or opinion about someone or something
find.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: Will Gary and Gail find happiness together?
She found the work very dull.
Lots of women I know find him attractive.
I found them quite easy to use.
Hyperactive children find it difficult to concentrate.
find it hard/easy/difficult etc (to do something)
find.translation[0].definitions[6].defin: to have the experience of discovering that something happens or is true
find.translation[0].definitions[6].examp: You might find that his work improves now he’s at a new school.
I find people are often surprised at how little it costs.
I think you’ll find more women entering the film business now.
I found the people to be charming and very friendly.
find.translation[0].definitions[7].defin: to succeed in getting enough of something, especially money, time, or energy, to be able to do something
find.translation[0].definitions[7].examp: He’s struggling to find the money for the trip.
Where are we going to find the time, the support, and the resources to do all this?
find.translation[0].definitions[8].defin: to make an official decision in a court of law
find.translation[0].definitions[8].examp: Both men were found guilty of illegally entering the country.
The tribunal found in favour of the defendant.
find.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: find
to get or see something that you have been searching for
Have you found your passport yet?
Police later found the car abandoned in a wood.
discover
to find something that was hidden or that people did not know about before
A second bomb has been discovered in south London.
locate
to find the exact position of something
The airline are still trying to locate my luggage.
Online maps make it easy to locate almost any place in the world.
come across something
to find something unexpectedly when you are not looking for it
I came across some old letters from my father in my drawer.
stumble on/across something
to find something unexpectedly, especially something very important
They may have stumbled across some vital evidence.
Completely by chance we had stumbled on the biggest hit of the year.
trace
to find someone or something that has disappeared, especially by a careful process of collecting information
She had given up all hope of tracing her missing daughter.
track somebody/something down
to find someone or something that is difficult to find by searching in different places
I’ve been trying to track down a book that’s out of print.
The police managed to track down the killer.
unearth
to find something that has been hidden or lost for a long time, by digging or searching for it
In 1796, a carved stone was unearthed near the burial mound.
find.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: something that someone finds, especially by digging or by searching under water
find.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: if you find work or employment, you get a job or some work. If you find someone to do a job, you employ them to do that job
find.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: Karenfound a job with a major travel company after she completed her course.
an assignment tofind a chief executivefor the American Council of Life Insurance
find.translation[2].definitions[1].defin: to discover or learn something by study or RESEARCH
find.translation[2].definitions[1].examp: We found 36% of customers interviewed said they had to wait between five and 10 minutes to be served.
The survey found that these drivers were more likely to drive badly and break the law.
find.translation[2].definitions[2].defin: if someone ACCUSED of a crime is found guilty or innocent, a court of law decides that they are guilty or innocent of that crime
find.translation[2].definitions[2].examp: All the senior executives were found guilty of conspiring to mislead the markets during the £837 million Blue Arrow rights issue.
find.translation[2].definitions[3].defin: to decide in a court of law whether someone is innocent or guilty of a crime
find.translation[2].definitions[3].examp: The Board of Review allowed the taxpayer’s appeal, but the High Court found for the Commissioner.
If the court finds against the bank, its bosses might be replaced with central-bank appointees.
find.translation[2].definitions[4].defin: if you find a computer file, you bring it up on your screen so that you can read it or write in it
find.translation[2].definitions[4].examp: Windows lets you find a file without having to remember which program you were using when you created it.
find.translation[2].definitions[5].defin: if you find an amount of money, you have enough money to allow you to do something
find.translation[2].definitions[5].examp: The first-time buyer has to find a deposit of 5% or more of the property price.
